steps.title: Wash the bamboo with a non-abrasive cloth, soap, and water before getting ready to change the color of bamboo.
steps.content: Wash the bamboo with a non-abrasive cloth, soap, and water before getting ready to change the color of bamboo. Allow the bamboo to dry completely.

steps.title: Use fine-grained sandpaper to lightly sand and remove the bamboo's natural waxy layer.
steps.content: Use fine-grained sandpaper to lightly sand and remove the bamboo's natural waxy layer. All bamboo has this layer, and it will prevent the bamboo fibers from accepting the stain. Pay particular attention to the rough areas of the bamboo that may be difficult to get to. If you leave any of the waxy layer, the bamboo will accept stain in some areas, but not in others. This will give the bamboo a mottled look. [1] X Research source Be aware that sanding the bamboo will change the character of the bamboo since it removes the bamboo's natural sheen and reduces the nodes. If the bamboo you desire to stain has been left out in the weather for several months, it may have turned a light gray color. Bamboo that has been weathered has lost its tough, waxy outer layer and will readily take a stain, varnish, or paint. Make sure that the bamboo is free of dust before you get started.

steps.title: Protect your work area with newspapers and your hands with rubber gloves.
steps.content: Protect your work area with newspapers and your hands with rubber gloves.

steps.title: Use circular motions with a sponge or rag to stain the bamboo.
steps.content: Use circular motions with a sponge or rag to stain the bamboo. Pay attention to the node areas. If you find that the bamboo is not taking the stain, wipe off the extra stain with a rag and allow the area to dry. Try re-sanding the area and then re-stain.

steps.title: Allow the stain to dry the specific number of hours recommended by the manufacturer.
steps.content: Allow the stain to dry the specific number of hours recommended by the manufacturer. Add several coats as needed to get the desired color. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Finish with a sealant that will bring back the shine and prevent the bamboo from drying out and becoming brittle.
steps.content: Finish with a sealant that will bring back the shine and prevent the bamboo from drying out and becoming brittle.

steps.title: Treat bamboo with heat to give it a darker look like fresh coffee.
steps.content: Treat bamboo with heat to give it a darker look like fresh coffee. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Drill holes at various spots down the length of the bamboo.
steps.content: Drill holes at various spots down the length of the bamboo.

steps.title: Toast the bamboo with a handheld torch.
steps.content: Toast the bamboo with a handheld torch. Gently move the torch back and forth down the length of the bamboo until the desired color is reached. [4] X Research source Work in 6-inch sections, and turn the bamboo as needed. Work all the way around before moving on. Finish with a wax paste to add shine to the bamboo and preserve it.
